titleproper.value: Guide to the Art Young Papers <num>TAM.046</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Tamiment staff, undated; Revised by Hillel Arnold, 2009

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-04-23T20:20:28</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Art Young was a cartoonist and socialist. The papers include correspondence, three original drawings, cartoons, clippings, postcards, printed material and catalogs of exhibits by artists working with political themes.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Art Young Papers; TAM 046; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Adelaide Schulkind Frank and Anna Friedkin in 1971. The accession number associated with this gift is 1971.004. Additional materials may have been donation by Albert Boni in 1972.

Art Young (1866-1943) was a leading socialist cartoonist and humorist whose work appeared in <title render="italic">The Masses</title>(1910-1917) and elsewhere. He was born in Monroe, Wisconsin, studied at the Academy of Design in Chicago, where he first illustrated news stories and saw his cartoons published in various newspapers. In 1895 Young moved to New York where his work was published in Life and where he became a socialist and, in 1910, one of the founding members of the artists and writers cooperative that produced <title render="italic">The Masses</title>, a socialist monthly. Young's work was among that cited by the U.S. government as being in violation of the World War I-inspired Espionage Act. Young's work also appeared in <title render="italic">The Liberator</title>(1918-1924), which he helped establish, his own radical humor magazine, <title render="italic">Good Morning</title>(1919-1921), the <title render="italic">New Leader</title>, the <title render="italic">New Masses</title>, <title render="italic">The Nation</title>, and elsewhere.

The papers include correspondence (principally outgoing), clippings, pamphlets, cartoons, printed material and catalogs of exhibits by artists working with political themes including Maurice Becker, Edmond McKenna, Archibald J. Motley, Jr. and Herman Rose some of these contain illustrations. The bulk of Young's letters are to Adelaide Schulkind, Meyer Friedkin and Arthur Spingarn. There is one letter each from William Gropper and Will Durant. The file on Young's death includes letters from John Haynes Holmes and Young's relatives. There are three original drawings, clippings from newspapers and periodicals, including the <title render="italic">New Masses</title>, containing cartoons by and articles about Young, a set of twelve postcards, <title render="italic">How to Cure World-Unrest</title>, New Year's cards (1936-39, 1941-44), an illustrated envelope (1943) designed to accompany an affixed poster-stamp by Gilbert Wilson, "Unity for Victory," on the theme of black-white unity, a typescript of Young's <title render="italic">Thomas Rowlandson</title>(1938), a biography of the 18th century cartoonist, publication correspondence for Young's autobiography, <title render="italic">Art Young, His Life and Times</title>(1939), including a letter from John Nicholas Beffel, and Young's last will and testament.
